title: ISSS608-VAA
text: Welcome to ISSS608 Visual Analytics and Applications. In this website, you will find my coursework prepared for this course.

title: About
text:
This website is my portfolio to showcase the different exercises that I have done to practice visualization skills and techniques.
Hands-on Exercises are pre-class preparation for our lectures.
In-Class Exercises are done during lectures to demonstrate important concepts taught by Prof. Kam Tin Seong.
Take-home Exercises are mini projects that allow me to apply the skills I have learnt.

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
The code chunk below uses p_load() of pacman package to check if tidyverse packages have been installed. If they are, then they will be launched into R.

pacman::p_load(tidyverse)






exam_data <-read_csv("Exam_data.csv")

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
Plotting a simple bar chart

ggplot(data=exam_data,
       aes(y=forcats::fct_infreq(RACE)))+
  geom_bar()+
  theme_minimal()+
  theme(
    panel.background = element_rect(fill = "lightblue", linetype=0))+
  labs(y="Race",
       x="Count")

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
section: Sorted bar charts with frequencies and percentages
text:
Sorted bar charts with frequencies and percentages

ggplot(data=exam_data,
       aes(x=forcats::fct_infreq(RACE)))+
  geom_bar()+
  ylim(0,220)+
  labs(x="Race",
       y="No. of\nPupils")+
  theme(axis.title.y=element_text(angle=0))+
  geom_text(stat="count", 
      aes(label=paste0(..count.., ", ", 
      round(..count../sum(..count..)*100, 1), "%")),
      vjust=-1)

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
section: Adding mean and median lines on histogram plot
text:
Adding mean and median lines on histogram plot

ggplot(data=exam_data,
       aes(x=MATHS))+
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 color='black', 
                 fill='lightblue')+
    labs(y="Count",
       x="Maths")+
    geom_vline(aes(xintercept=mean(MATHS, na.rm=T)),
             color="red", 
             linetype="dashed", 
             size=1)+
    geom_vline(aes(xintercept=median(MATHS, na.rm=T)),
             color="grey30",
             linetype="dashed", 
             size=1)

title: Hands-on Exercise 1
text:
Background histogram for added context

ggplot(data=exam_data,
       aes(x=ENGLISH, fill=GENDER))+
  geom_histogram(data=exam_data[,-3], fill='grey', alpha=0.5)+
  geom_histogram(colour='black')+
  facet_wrap(~GENDER)+
  guides(fill="none")+
  theme_bw()

title: Hands-on Exercise 2
text:
Anotation

Anotation with ggrepel
Replace geom_text() by geom_text_repel() and geom_label() by geom_label_repel.

ggplot(data=exam_data,
       aes(y=ENGLISH,x=MATHS))+
  geom_point()+
  ggtitle("English scores versus Maths scores for Primary 3")+
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100))+
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              size=0.5)+
  geom_label_repel(aes(label = ID), 
                   fontface = "bold")

title: Hands-on Exercise 2
text:
Composite graphs

Pathwork methods

Creating a composite figure with tag

p1 <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x = MATHS)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="grey25", 
                 fill="grey90") + 
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("Distribution of Maths scores")

p2 <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x = ENGLISH)) +
  geom_histogram(bins=20, 
                 boundary = 100,
                 color="grey25", 
                 fill="grey90") +
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("Distribution of English scores")

p3 <- ggplot(data=exam_data, 
             aes(x= MATHS, 
                 y=ENGLISH)) +
  geom_point() +
  geom_smooth(method=lm, 
              size=0.5) +  
  coord_cartesian(xlim=c(0,100),
                  ylim=c(0,100)) +
  ggtitle("English scores versus Maths scores for Primary 3")


#“|” operator to stack two ggplot2 graphs
#“/” operator to place the plots beside each other
#“()” operator the define the sequence of the plotting
((p1 / p2) | p3) + 
  plot_annotation(tag_levels = 'I')






Creating figure with insert

p12 <- p1|p2
p3 + inset_element(p2, 
                   left = 0.02, 
                   bottom = 0.7, 
                   right = 0.5, 
                   top = 1)






Creating a composite figure by using patchwork and ggtheme

patchwork <- (p1 / p2) | p3
patchwork & theme_economist()
